This is the most basic and most widely used type of tapered roller bearing. It consists of two main separable parts: the cone (inner ring) assembly and the cup (outer ring). It is typically mounted in opposing pairs on a shaft

Matched tapered roller bearings arranged face-to-face (X-arrangement, load lines diverge towards the bearing axis) accommodate high radial loads and axial loads in both directions. The precision manufactured intermediate ring between the outer rings enables a defined internal clearance or preload to be achieved when mounted. Matched tapered roller bearings are typically used in gearboxes, hoisting equipment, rolling mills, and machines in the mining industry.
High radial load carrying capacity
Designed for axial loads in both directions
Relatively high stiffness
Surface finish on the contact surfaces of the rollers and raceways that enhances operational reliability

Name: F-586062.ZL
description: The FAG F-586062.ZL, crafted by Schaeffler Group in Germany, is a high-performance cylindrical roller bearing engineered for railway axlebox assemblies. Designed to withstand heavy radial and axial loads, this bearing ensures reliable, maintenance-free operation in demanding rail environments, including trains, trams, and subways.

Name: SL04-5018
description: The SL04-5018NR NTN is a full-complement double-row cylindrical roller bearing. This bearing has a particularly high radial load capacity. The design consists of a solid inner and outer ring with a double row of cylindrical rollers. These rolling elements are guided between flanges. Since there is no cage, a maximum number of rollers can be used. This type of bearing is therefore suitable for very heavy loads where lower rotational speeds are involved.

description: The SL045020-D INA is a full-complement double-row cylindrical roller bearing. This bearing has a particularly high radial load capacity. Name: SL045014PP

Name: SL18-3016
description: The SL183016 is a single-row, full-complement cylinder bearing. This bearing type has a solid outer and inner ring and a high number of cylindrical rollers. These rollers are guided between the ribs of the rings. Since there is no cage, the maximum number of rolls can be used. As a result, these bearings can support very high radial loads. However, the maximum speed is lower than the speed of cylindrical roller bearings with cages. Single-row full-complement cylindrical roller bearings can also support axial forces in one direction. They are used as support bearings. Support bearings allow axial displacement of the shaft relative to the housing in one direction. The shaft is located axially in the other direction.

Name: NNF5011-2LS-V
description: Double row full complement cylindrical roller bearings incorporate a maximum number of rollers and are therefore suitable for very heavy radial loads in combination with moderate speeds. Having three flanges on the two-piece inner ring and one central flange on the outer ring, NNF design bearings can locate the shaft axially in both directions. Two snap ring grooves in the outer ring simplify mounting and save space axially.

The 5408A SKF is a double-row angular contact ball bearing with solid inner- and outer rings. The design of this bearing type resembles two single-row angular contact ball bearings in O-arrangement but is slightly narrower. Double-row angular contact ball bearings can support high radial forces and axial forces in both directions. The greater the contact angle, the greater the axial load capacity of the bearing.

The 7328B NSK is a single row angular contact bearing. These bearings have solid inner- and outer rings. They owe their name to the contact angle that is created as the raceways of the inner and outer rings are offset from each other along the bearing axis. The bearing rings have one high and one low shoulder. Thanks to the low shoulder, a large number of balls can be incorporated in the bearing. Single row angular contact bearings can support high radial forces and axial forces in one direction. The greater the contact angle, the greater the axial load capacity of the bearing.

Self-aligning ball bearings have two rows of balls, a common sphered raceway in the outer ring and two deep uninterrupted raceway grooves in the inner ring. They are insensitive to angular misalignment of the shaft relative to the housing, which can be caused, for example, by shaft deflection.
